messages.content: What is the abstract of the QALY flow paper?

In a world where biological lifespan has no fixed upper bound, yet individuals remain vulnerable to stochastic catastrophic failures (accidents, disease, irreparable breakdown) and also experience repairable degradation requiring ongoing maintenance, lifetime-summed health metrics become structurally ill-suited for public policy. This note gives a foundation for evaluation based on \emph{steady per-unit-time} health value: a regenerative (renewal) QALY flow defined as a ratio of expected cycle reward to expected cycle duration, together with compatible notions of cost-effectiveness, stability under perturbations, and explicit extensions for irreversibility and risk/volatility. The framework is stated as axioms plus a controlled continuous-time model and yields standard existence and sensitivity results under transparent conditions.
Describe the stylized world setting assumed by the QALY flow framework.

We assume the following stylized world:

\begin{itemize}
\item There is \emph{no fixed biological maximum lifespan}. Conditional on avoiding catastrophic failure and receiving ongoing care, individuals can persist indefinitely.
\item Catastrophic failures still occur stochastically (accidents, lethal disease, irreparable system failure).
\item Many degradations are \emph{repairable}, with maintenance and replacement restoring function at monetary, time, and quality costs.
\end{itemize}

Public policy must allocate scarce resources among prevention, monitoring, maintenance, repair technologies, environments, and protections against catastrophic risks.
State all six axioms of the QALY flow framework.
Define the state space, quality function, and irreversibility partition with full mathematical notation.

Let $\mathcal{S}$ denote the set of \emph{alive} health states. Let $\dagger$ denote catastrophic failure (death/irreparable loss), which is absorbing. Define $\mathcal{X} \coloneqq \mathcal{S} \cup \{\dagger\}$. This multi-state formulation follows the health economics tradition of modeling health trajectories as stochastic processes.

A measurable function $q:\mathcal{X}\to[0,1]$ gives instantaneous quality, with $q(\dagger)=0$. The quality function assigns health-related quality of life to each state, following established measurement frameworks.

We also designate a subset $\mathcal{I}\subseteq \mathcal{S}$ of \emph{irreversible harm} states and $\mathcal{R} \coloneqq \mathcal{S}\setminus \mathcal{I}$ of \emph{reversible/repairable} states. This partition is conceptual and policy-relevant: interventions can reduce transitions into $\mathcal{I}$, increase repair success out of $\mathcal{R}$, or alter time spent in low-quality downtime states.
Define the action space, cost function, and policy structure.

For each $x\in\mathcal{S}$, let $\mathcal{A}(x)$ be a nonempty set of admissible actions (prevention intensity, monitoring, repair protocol, environment, replacement choice). A (possibly history-dependent) policy $\pi$ selects actions over time.

Let $c:\mathcal{S}\times \mathcal{A} \to [0,\infty)$ be a measurable running cost; set $c(\dagger,\cdot)=0$.
How are health dynamics modeled as a controlled continuous-time process?

We model health dynamics as a controlled continuous-time process $(X_t)_{t\ge 0}$ on $\mathcal{X}$ (e.g.\ a controlled CTMC or more general controlled jump process). Under action $a\in \mathcal{A}(x)$ at alive state $x$, transitions are governed by a rate kernel $Q(\cdot\mid x,a)$ with $\dagger$ absorbing:
\[
Q(\dagger\mid \dagger,a)=0,\qquad Q(y\mid \dagger,a)=0\;\;\forall y\neq \dagger.
\]

Define the catastrophic time
\[
\tau \coloneqq \inf\{t\ge 0: X_t=\dagger\}.
\]
State the assumption about bounded quality and well-defined dynamics.
What are sufficient conditions for non-explosiveness of the controlled health process?
State the regeneration/replacement assumption.
Explain the large-population interpretation of the regeneration assumption.

\begin{remark}[Large-population interpretation]
The regeneration assumption is best understood as modeling a large stationary population where catastrophic failures and new entrants are rare and approximately uncorrelated. In this interpretation:
\begin{itemize}
\item The regenerative cycle represents the expected trajectory of a randomly sampled individual from the cross-section.
\item The ratio $J(\pi)$ equals the cross-sectional average quality at any point in time under demographic steady-state.
\item ``Immediate replacement'' reflects the continuous demographic flow in a large population, not a claim about literal individual replacement.
\item ``Independence'' follows from population size: any single death is statistically uncorrelated with the vast pool of existing individuals.
\item ``Identical initial distribution'' reflects the stationary assumption---we are modeling the steady-state regime, not the transition from bounded to unbounded lifespans.
\end{itemize}
This interpretation dissolves concerns about the literal plausibility of i.i.d.\ replacement by reframing the assumption as a consequence of the modeling target (cross-sectional welfare in a stationary population) rather than an empirical claim about individual-level dynamics.
\end{remark}
Define cycle reward and cycle cost.

Under a policy $\pi$ and initial distribution $\nu$, define per-cycle quantities:
\begin{align}
R^\pi &\coloneqq \int_0^{\tau} q(X_t)\,dt, \\
C^\pi &\coloneqq \int_0^{\tau} c(X_t,A_t)\,dt, \\
\tau^\pi &\coloneqq \tau.
\end{align}
By the bounded quality assumption, $0\le R^\pi \le \tau^\pi$ almost surely.
Define steady QALY flow and steady cost flow.
Explain risk neutrality in the base QALY flow framework.

\begin{remark}[Risk neutrality in the base framework]
The objective $J(\pi)$ depends only on expected cycle reward and expected cycle duration, not on their variances or higher moments. This embeds a \emph{risk-neutral} preference: two policies with identical $J(\pi)$ but different cycle-to-cycle volatility in quality are treated as equally desirable.

When risk aversion is desired, this can be addressed via explicit extensions: either by adding an explicit risk penalty (e.g., $J(\pi) - \lambda\sqrt{\text{Var}(\bar{q}^\pi)}$) or by applying coherent risk measures (e.g., CVaR) to cycle-level outcomes. The base framework is risk-neutral by design, leaving risk preferences as an explicit parameter to be chosen by the policy maker.
\end{remark}
State and prove the basic boundedness proposition for QALY flow.
State the renewal-reward theorem for QALY flow.

Under the regeneration assumption, successive cycles are i.i.d.\ with cycle lengths $\tau_1,\tau_2,\dots$ and cycle rewards $R_1,R_2,\dots$ distributed as $(\tau^\pi,R^\pi)$.

Let $Q(T)\coloneqq \int_0^T q(X_t)\,dt$ be cumulative quality in the regenerative process.

\begin{theorem}[Renewal-reward representation]
Assume $\mathbb{E}_\nu[\tau^\pi]\in(0,\infty)$. Then
\[
\frac{Q(T)}{T}\xrightarrow[T\to\infty]{a.s.} J(\pi),
\qquad\text{and}\qquad
\mathbb{E}\!\left[\frac{Q(T)}{T}\right]\to J(\pi).
\]
\end{theorem}

\begin{remark}
This theorem is the central justification: $J(\pi)$ is the asymptotic average quality per unit person-time sustained by policy $\pi$ under a continuing regime. This directly satisfies the well-posedness, horizon invariance, and person-time axioms.
\end{remark}
Define truncated steady QALY flow for handling infinite expected cycles.

Unbounded lifespan allows policies for which $\mathbb{E}_\nu[\tau^\pi]=\infty$. Rather than impose a discount rate to force finiteness, we adopt an explicit truncation-based normalization that preserves explicit normativity.

\begin{definition}[Truncated steady QALY flow]
For $T>0$, define
\[
R_T^\pi \coloneqq \int_0^{\tau\wedge T} q(X_t)\,dt,\qquad
\tau_T^\pi \coloneqq \tau\wedge T,
\]
and define
\[
J^+(\pi)\coloneqq \limsup_{T\to\infty}\frac{\mathbb{E}_\nu[R_T^\pi]}{\mathbb{E}_\nu[\tau_T^\pi]},
\qquad
J^-(\pi)\coloneqq \liminf_{T\to\infty}\frac{\mathbb{E}_\nu[R_T^\pi]}{\mathbb{E}_\nu[\tau_T^\pi]}.
\]
When $J^+(\pi)=J^-(\pi)$, denote the common value by $J(\pi)$.
\end{definition}
Prove that truncated QALY flow is well-posed and bounded.
State and prove the convergence of truncated QALY flow.
Describe stationary Markov policies and the scalarized optimization objective.

Restrict attention to stationary Markov policies $f$ choosing $a=f(x)\in\mathcal{A}(x)$ when in state $x$. Under such $f$, the process becomes time-homogeneous.

A policy objective can be scalarized as maximizing net steady welfare
\[
W_\lambda(f)\coloneqq J(f)-\lambda K(f),
\]
with $\lambda>0$ as an explicit willingness-to-pay parameter, or as a constrained problem maximizing $J(f)$ subject to $K(f)\le \bar{K}$.
State the finite controlled CTMC assumption and the optimal policy existence theorem.
Explain computational approaches for QALY flow optimization.
Why is perturbation stability important for QALY flow?

Practical policy evaluation requires understanding sensitivity to parameter uncertainty, which can be substantial in health economic models. A policy metric used for governance should vary continuously under small parameter changes (accident rate estimates, repair success probabilities, cost inputs).

Let $\theta$ index model parameters (transition rates, repair probabilities, etc.), and write $J_\theta(\pi)$ for the QALY flow computed in model $\theta$.
State the assumptions required for Lipschitz stability of QALY flow.

\begin{assumption}[Uniform lower bound on expected cycle length]
There exists $m>0$ such that for all policies $\pi$ in a policy class $\Pi$ and parameters $\theta$ in a neighborhood of interest,
\[
\mathbb{E}_{\nu,\theta}[\tau^\pi]\ge m.
\]
\end{assumption}

\begin{assumption}[Lipschitz cycle-level expectations]
There exist constants $L_R,L_\tau\ge 0$ and a metric $d(\cdot,\cdot)$ on parameter space such that for all $\pi\in\Pi$,
\[
\left|\mathbb{E}_{\nu,\theta}[R^\pi]-\mathbb{E}_{\nu,\theta'}[R^\pi]\right|\le L_R\, d(\theta,\theta'),
\qquad
\left|\mathbb{E}_{\nu,\theta}[\tau^\pi]-\mathbb{E}_{\nu,\theta'}[\tau^\pi]\right|\le L_\tau\, d(\theta,\theta').
\]
\end{assumption}
What are sufficient conditions for the Lipschitz stability assumptions?

\begin{remark}[Sufficient conditions for the stability assumptions]
The uniform lower bound assumption holds if there is a uniform lower bound $\mu>0$ on the total exit rate from $\dagger$-free states: $\inf_{x\in\mathcal{S},a\in\mathcal{A}(x)} Q(\dagger\mid x,a) \ge \mu$ implies $\mathbb{E}[\tau^\pi]\le 1/\mu$ is bounded above, and a positive catastrophe rate from some state reachable under $\nu$ gives $\mathbb{E}[\tau^\pi]\ge m>0$.

For the Lipschitz assumption, if transition rates $Q_\theta(y\mid x,a)$ are Lipschitz in $\theta$ uniformly over $x,a,y$, then standard perturbation bounds for Markov chain expectations (via Dynkin's formula or coupling arguments) yield Lipschitz continuity of $\mathbb{E}_\theta[R^\pi]$ and $\mathbb{E}_\theta[\tau^\pi]$.
\end{remark}
State and prove the Lipschitz stability theorem for QALY flow.

\begin{theorem}[Lipschitz stability of QALY flow]
Under the uniform lower bound and Lipschitz cycle-level expectations assumptions,
\[
\left|J_\theta(\pi)-J_{\theta'}(\pi)\right|
\le \frac{L_R+L_\tau}{m}\, d(\theta,\theta')
\qquad\text{for all }\pi\in\Pi.
\]
\end{theorem}

\begin{proof}
Write $J_\theta(\pi)=\frac{a}{b}$ and $J_{\theta'}(\pi)=\frac{a'}{b'}$ with
$a=\mathbb{E}_{\theta}[R^\pi]$, $b=\mathbb{E}_{\theta}[\tau^\pi]$, and similarly for $a',b'$.
We use the identity
\[
\frac{a}{b}-\frac{a'}{b'} = \frac{a b' - a' b}{b b'} = \frac{(a-a')b' + a'(b'-b)}{b b'}.
\]
Taking absolute values and applying the triangle inequality:
\[
\left|\frac{a}{b}-\frac{a'}{b'}\right|
\le \frac{|a-a'|\cdot b' + |a'|\cdot|b'-b|}{b\cdot b'}
= \frac{|a-a'|}{b} + \frac{a'}{b'}\cdot\frac{|b-b'|}{b}.
\]
Since $0\le R^\pi\le\tau^\pi$ a.s., we have $0\le a'\le b'$, so $a'/b'\le 1$. By the lower bound assumption, $b\ge m>0$. Thus:
\[
\left|\frac{a}{b}-\frac{a'}{b'}\right|
\le \frac{|a-a'|}{m} + \frac{|b-b'|}{m}.
\]
Applying the Lipschitz assumption yields the result.
\end{proof}
Summarize the stability story for QALY flow.
Introduce the irreversibility and risk extensions section.

The steady flow $J(\pi)$ is the core foundation. In a maintenance world, two further dimensions commonly matter and can be added without breaking the framework: irreversibility and risk/volatility. Some health states represent irreversible conditions with distinct mortality profiles. The distinction between healthspan and lifespan is naturally captured by partitioning states into reversible and absorbing subsets.
How can irreversibility be incorporated as a penalty or constraint?
State the minimum cycle length assumption for risk measures.

\begin{assumption}[Minimum cycle length for risk measures]
There exists $\epsilon>0$ such that $\tau^\pi \ge \epsilon$ almost surely.
\end{assumption}

Under this assumption, the within-cycle average quality $\bar{q}^\pi \coloneqq R^\pi/\tau^\pi$ is well-defined and bounded: $\bar{q}^\pi\in[0,1]$ a.s.
Define risk-sensitive QALY flow objectives.

Average flow can hide instability. We define risk measures that are always well-defined.

Under the minimum cycle length assumption, one can evaluate risk-sensitive objectives such as:
\[
J_{\mathrm{MV},\lambda}(\pi)\coloneqq J(\pi)-\lambda \sqrt{\mathrm{Var}(\bar{q}^\pi)},
\]
where the variance is finite since $\bar{q}^\pi\in[0,1]$.

Alternatively, when the minimum cycle length assumption may not hold, use risk measures applied directly to the cycle reward $R^\pi$ (which is always well-defined):
\[
J_{\mathrm{CVaR},\alpha}(\pi) \coloneqq \frac{\mathrm{CVaR}_\alpha(R^\pi)}{\mathbb{E}[\tau^\pi]},
\]
where $\mathrm{CVaR}_\alpha$ is the conditional value-at-risk at level $\alpha\in(0,1)$.

The parameter $\lambda$ (or $\alpha$) is an explicit normative risk-aversion coefficient.
Define the flow-based ICER (incremental cost-effectiveness ratio).

Our flow-based ICER parallels the standard incremental cost-effectiveness ratio, but replaces discounted sums with long-run averages. This avoids the well-documented issues with discount rate selection.

\begin{definition}[Flow ICER]
For two policies $\pi_1,\pi_2$ with $J(\pi_2)\neq J(\pi_1)$, define
\[
\mathrm{ICER}_{\mathrm{flow}}(\pi_1\to\pi_2)\coloneqq
\frac{K(\pi_2)-K(\pi_1)}{J(\pi_2)-J(\pi_1)}.
\]
\end{definition}

\begin{remark}
This answers a governance-relevant question: the ongoing resource cost per unit improvement in sustained quality per unit person-time.
\end{remark}
Introduce distributional aggregation and explicit ethics.

The distributional extension follows the framework of distributional cost-effectiveness analysis, which assigns equity weights to different population subgroups. Research shows that the value of health improvements depends on access to insurance and retirement products, suggesting distributional weights should account for financial as well as health heterogeneity.

Let groups be indexed by $i$ with repaired flows $J_i(\pi)$.
Describe weighted additive welfare for distributional aggregation.

\paragraph{Weighted additive welfare.}
\[
SW(\pi)=\sum_i w_i\,J_i(\pi),
\]
with explicit weights $w_i$ encoding priority rules.
Describe inequality-averse welfare for distributional aggregation.

\paragraph{Inequality-averse welfare.}
\[
SW(\pi)=\sum_i u(J_i(\pi)),
\]
with concave $u$ encoding diminishing social marginal value.
Describe minimum-acceptable flow constraints.

\paragraph{Minimum-acceptable flow.}
Impose a hard constraint $J_i(\pi)\ge J_{\min}$ for all $i$ (or a bound on time spent below a quality floor). This is a normative commitment that becomes unavoidable to state clearly when lives can be arbitrarily long.
What is the conclusion of the QALY flow paper?

We proposed a foundation for health policy evaluation in an unbounded-lifespan, maintenance-driven world by taking \emph{steady person-time value} as the primary object. Under a regenerative regime interpretation, QALY flow $J(\pi)=\mathbb{E}[R^\pi]/\mathbb{E}[\tau^\pi]$ is bounded, horizon-invariant, and has a direct long-run meaning via renewal-reward theory. The same construction yields steady cost flow and a natural cost-effectiveness ratio. Stability under parameter perturbations reduces to checkable cycle-level conditions. Irreversibility and risk/volatility enter cleanly as explicit penalties or constraints, keeping all ethical commitments exposed rather than embedded in discounting.
State and prove the cross-sectional sampling interpretation.

In the regenerative process, let $U_T$ be uniform on $[0,T]$ independent of the process.

\begin{proposition}[Cross-sectional interpretation]
Assume $\mathbb{E}_\nu[\tau^\pi]\in(0,\infty)$. Then
\[
\mathbb{E}[q(X_{U_T})] \to J(\pi) \quad \text{as }T\to\infty.
\]
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
This is the ``inspection paradox'' form of the renewal-reward theorem. By the key renewal theorem, under $\mathbb{E}[\tau^\pi]<\infty$, the distribution of the state at a uniformly random time converges to the stationary distribution weighted by sojourn time, and the expected quality under this distribution equals $J(\pi)$.
\end{proof}

Thus $J(\pi)$ can be read as the expected quality of a randomly sampled person-time under the regime.
Explain the relation between QALY flow and discounting.

The health economics literature extensively debates discounting. Researchers analyze the decision-theoretic foundations, showing that different discount rates for costs and effects can be justified under certain conditions. Others examine how time enters health evaluations more broadly.

Our approach sidesteps the discount rate selection problem entirely by moving to ratio-form objectives. Rather than summing discounted utilities (which requires choosing a discount rate that becomes arbitrary over unbounded horizons), we define welfare as quality per unit time, which is inherently bounded and horizon-invariant.

Why does the QALY flow framework use a regenerative regime instead of discounting?

Health technology assessment relies on established frameworks for comparing interventions, but these presuppose finite planning horizons. As longevity science advances the prospect of radical healthspan extension, fundamental questions arise about how to evaluate policies when lifespans may be unbounded.

The extensive literature on discounting in health economics has debated time preference, but unbounded horizons require a more fundamental rethinking. When lifespans become unbounded, traditional discounted QALYs diverge to infinity or become arbitrarily sensitive to the choice of discount rate. The regenerative regime provides a natural alternative: rather than discounting future welfare, we measure welfare as a rate (quality per unit time), which remains bounded and meaningful regardless of horizon length.
How should a policymaker interpret and use the QALY flow metric $J(\pi)$ in practice?

The QALY flow $J(\pi) = \mathbb{E}_\nu[R^\pi]/\mathbb{E}_\nu[\tau^\pi]$ has three complementary interpretations that guide practical use:

\paragraph{Long-run time average.} By the renewal-reward theorem, $J(\pi)$ is the limit of cumulative quality divided by elapsed time: $\lim_{T\to\infty} Q(T)/T \to J(\pi)$ almost surely. This means $J(\pi)$ represents the sustained quality per unit time under policy $\pi$ over arbitrarily long horizons.

\paragraph{Cross-sectional average.} Under demographic steady-state, $J(\pi)$ equals the expected quality-of-life of a randomly sampled person-time. If a policymaker samples the population at a random moment and measures quality, the average converges to $J(\pi)$. This makes $J(\pi)$ directly interpretable as population health status.

\paragraph{Cycle-level structure.} $J(\pi)$ decomposes as expected cycle reward divided by expected cycle duration. Policy interventions affect both numerator (improving quality during alive states) and denominator (extending expected lifespan to catastrophic failure). A policy that increases $R^\pi$ by 10\% but also increases $\tau^\pi$ by 10\% leaves $J(\pi)$ unchanged---the framework correctly treats sustained quality per unit time as the relevant metric.

\paragraph{Practical workflow.}
\begin{enumerate}
\item Estimate transition rates $Q(\cdot\mid x,a)$, quality function $q(x)$, and cost function $c(x,a)$ from clinical and economic data.
\item Solve the controlled Markov process to compute $\mathbb{E}_\nu[R^\pi]$, $\mathbb{E}_\nu[\tau^\pi]$, and $\mathbb{E}_\nu[C^\pi]$ for each candidate policy $\pi$.
\item Compute $J(\pi)$ and $K(\pi)$ for each policy.
\item Compare policies via $\mathrm{ICER}_{\mathrm{flow}}$ or scalarized objective $W_\lambda(\pi) = J(\pi) - \lambda K(\pi)$ with explicit willingness-to-pay $\lambda$.
\item Conduct sensitivity analysis via the Lipschitz stability theorem to bound $|J_\theta(\pi) - J_{\theta'}(\pi)|$ under parameter uncertainty.
\end{enumerate}

This workflow avoids arbitrary discount rate selection and produces a bounded, horizon-invariant metric suitable for governance decisions under potentially unbounded lifespans.

\section{Setting and design requirements}

Health technology assessment relies on established frameworks for comparing interventions, but these presuppose finite planning horizons. As longevity science advances the prospect of radical healthspan extension, fundamental questions arise about how to evaluate policies when lifespans may be unbounded. The extensive literature on discounting in health economics has debated time preference, but unbounded horizons require a more fundamental rethinking.
Write the introduction to Section 1.2 (Axioms).

\subsection{Axioms (explicitly normative and structural)}
We state the requirements as axioms. Some are structural (needed for a usable metric), others encode transparent normative choices. Axioms~2--4 in particular reflect welfarist and experientialist commitments that, while standard in health economics, are substantive ethical positions rather than purely structural requirements.
